history.content:
Didn't take it with Shewchuk so perhaps you should take my input with a pinch of salt. There is no textbook available for the course although Shewchuk's notes are made available (and they are very good!). That being said, I highly recommend going to lecture anyway - I found multiple exposure to the material to be very helpful.

I really enjoyed the homework and assessments largely because they are rather math-y (my home department is Math); they definitely were much more so than any other CS course I've taken. That being said, the Math definitely isn't inaccessible for the average CS major - I worked with a couple L&S CS majors whose most intense exposure to math was Math 54 and they did pretty alright themselves, after a brief adjustment period. (Although it is unquestionable that more serious math in the form of Math 110/EE 127 would be immensely helpful for doing well). The first few assignments tend to be the most math-y and it seemed to me that the instructors made it more so this way to frighten more people into dropping the course (since there was definitely wayyyyy too many people enrolled at the start of the semester). If math isn't your thing but coding is, stick with it anyway; the math content in the homeworks drop significantly after the drop deadline. I would estimate that at least 50% of the assignments are purely coding-intensive while the math-intensive assignments have coding-heavy portions anyway. 

As for study strategies, (related to the above), I personally went through the entire problem set by myself on the first pass, putting significant effort into each problem, before I started working with other people (more about this in a bit) on further passes. This is a general strategy of mine for all courses, not just 189, and it's served me quite well thus far. I cannot emphasize how important it is to attempt each problem yourself; the assignments are the best form of exposure to ML-type math you will get and such exposure is crucial to doing well on exams (when I took the course, there were no multiple-choice questions that tested core domain knowledge, only math. I know that Shewchuk previously had multiple-choice questions; whether he changes this policy remains to be seen).

As for study groups, I would highly recommend working with a group with a diverse background and skill set. This is always a good idea, but perhaps more so than ever in 189, which tends to operate at the intersection of multiple fields (Math, Stat, CS and more). My background is primarily in Math and Stat and my coding ability is decent at best (even saying that might be pushing it); I am not too sure I would have got through the course totally sane without having friends with significantly stronger programming skills to work with in the coding-intensive projects (and I'm sure they'd say the same about my Math/Stat help).

I personally felt that one extremely underrated resource are discussion sections; the TAs in 189 - as in most CS courses - are obviously brilliant and were logistically-speaking, the saving grace in this otherwise very disorganized course. Discussion sections were my one form of further exposure to ML-type math and I felt, the single greatest resource I had in preparing for finals were the discussion worksheets. In addition to helping reinforce the material, the worksheets provided further familiarity with exam-type problems; since the TAs design these worksheets as well as the exams, it is perhaps no surprise that being able to do well in the former generally translates to doing well in the latter. (Quick note about finals: the finals in 189 - multiple-choice portions aside - are without doubt, some of the best written and most interesting exams I have ever seen. Another testament to the quality of the instructors).

Finally, this is said all the time but I don't think enough students heed this advice; office hours is a great resource. Go to OH (a great, general tip for all classes), and not just if when you get stuck on the assignments.

children.subject: Took them concurrently last semester. They overlapped in terms of terminology (mean, variance, etc.) but not in terms of the actual problems encountered. I don't think either course helps that much with the other. In terms of preparing for 126, CS 70 is probably the most helpful.

Can't comment on 126 exactly, but I took Stat 134 the semester prior to taking CS189 and I found it to be quite helpful. As Allen mentioned, the problems are quite different, but I felt the intuition and grasp of probability I got from 134 to be quite helpful in 189, especially with conceptually understanding certain derivations.

Don't think 189 would be particularly helpful for 126/134 tho.

Agreed, probability intuition is important. Independence, Bayes' rule, expectation, and variance/covariance show up a lot in 189.

Also, +1 to everything Malayandi said in the student answer above, especially w.r.t. study strategies and working with a group.
How much is EE126 related? Would taking them concurrently help? Does CS189 first better prepare you for EE126 after?

If you've taken Math 110, Stat 134, Stat 135 and CS 170 before 189, you'll be more prepared than most already. One thing I'd recommend taking if you're trying to go overkill on the prep is EE127. I'd say 127 is perhaps more useful for 189 (and most things in general) than most of those courses you listed.

I heard some students who took CS189 in Fall 2016 complaining that they weren't prepared for the math in CS189. Does anyone know what math that might be? And what class(es) out of the CS/EE/STAT/Math departments teach that math? 

I was planning on just taking M110, CS70, and STAT134 as my prep for 189. I will also have taken CS170 and STAT 135 before 189, though I wasn't planning on those specifically being of particular use in prepping for 189. Are there any other courses that might be good to take before 189?

history.content:
I'm taking it next semester. I know plenty of people have offered advice on the prerequisite math needed, but what about study strategies? 

Specifically people who took it with Shewchuk, did people find his lectures informative? Detailed? Helpful? Should we rely on a textbook? What kinds of study strategies did people find effective? How are the homeworks and assessments?

Thanks!
history.subject: Tips for CS 189?
